reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s worry that value-destroying threats could largely negate the optimism from moral trade (a meaningful but not load-bearing pillar of the overall argument, which also rests heavily on skepticism about WAM-convergence and various blockers), so centrality is moderate. However, it only partially weakens that threat-based pessimism: symmetric access to superintelligence can increase deterrence, but threats/extortion can still be rational and value-destroying even under symmetry (e.g., credible commitment, bargaining pathologies, targeting agents with asymmetric values, coordination failures, and the essay’s point that even small executed-threat fractions can dominate on many axiologies). The critique also somewhat mischaracterizes the essay as assuming an unargued offense–defense asymmetry; the essay’s argument leans more on axiological sensitivity to bads and the existence/credibility of threats than on established offense-dominance. Still, the objection is coherent, relevant, and clearly stated with little fluff.
title: Symmetric access to superintelligence should enable deterrence alongside threats
